sn22.79:1.2: “Mendicants, whatever ascetics and brahmins recollect many kinds of past lives, all recollect the five grasping aggregates, or one of them.
sn22.79:1.4: ‘I had such form in the past.’
sn22.79:1.5: Recollecting thus, it’s only form that they recollect.
sn22.79:1.11: Recollecting thus, it’s only consciousness that they recollect.
sn22.79:2.1: And why do you call it form?
sn22.79:2.2: It’s deformed; that’s why it’s called ‘form’.
sn22.79:2.4: Deformed by cold, heat, hunger, and thirst, and deformed by the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles.
sn22.79:2.5: It’s deformed; that’s why it’s called ‘form’.
sn22.79:3.1: And why do you call it feeling?
sn22.79:3.2: It feels; that’s why it’s called ‘feeling’.
sn22.79:3.4: It feels pleasure, pain, and neutral.
sn22.79:3.5: It feels; that’s why it’s called ‘feeling’.
sn22.79:4.1: And why do you call it perception?
sn22.79:4.2: It perceives; that’s why it’s called ‘perception’.
sn22.79:4.4: It perceives blue, yellow, red, and white.
sn22.79:4.5: It perceives; that’s why it’s called ‘perception’.
sn22.79:5.1: And why do you call them choices?
sn22.79:5.2: Choices produce conditioned phenomena; that’s why they’re called ‘choices’.
sn22.79:5.3: And what are the conditioned phenomena that they produce?
sn22.79:5.4: Form is a conditioned phenomenon; choices are what make it into form. Feeling is a conditioned phenomenon; choices are what make it into feeling. Perception is a conditioned phenomenon; choices are what make it into perception. Choices are conditioned phenomena; choices are what make them into choices. Consciousness is a conditioned phenomenon; choices are what make it into consciousness.
sn22.79:5.5: Choices produce conditioned phenomena; that’s why they’re called ‘choices’.
sn22.79:6.1: And why do you call it consciousness?
sn22.79:6.2: It cognizes; that’s why it’s called ‘consciousness’.
sn22.79:6.4: It cognizes sour, bitter, pungent, sweet, hot, mild, salty, and bland.
sn22.79:6.5: It cognizes; that’s why it’s called ‘consciousness’.
sn22.79:7.1: A learned noble disciple reflects on this:
sn22.79:7.3: In the past I was also bitten by form just like now.
sn22.79:7.4: If I were to look forward to enjoying form in the future, I’d be bitten by form in the future just as I am today.’
sn22.79:7.5: Reflecting like this they are not concerned with past form,
sn22.79:7.6: they don’t look forward to enjoying future form,
sn22.79:7.7: and they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding present form.
sn22.79:10.2: In the past I was also bitten by consciousness just like now.
sn22.79:10.3: If I were to look forward to enjoying consciousness in the future, I’d be bitten by consciousness in the future just as I am today.’
sn22.79:10.5: Reflecting like this they are not concerned with past consciousness,
sn22.79:10.6: they don’t look forward to enjoying future consciousness,
sn22.79:10.7: and they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding present consciousness.
sn22.79:11.4: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn22.79:11.6: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn22.79:11.7: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn22.79:11.14: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn22.79:11.16: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn22.79:11.17: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn22.79:11.19: “So you should truly see any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
sn22.79:11.20: You should truly see any kind of feeling …
sn22.79:11.23: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
sn22.79:12.1: This is called a noble disciple who gets rid of and doesn’t accumulate;
sn22.79:12.2: who gives up and doesn’t grasp;
sn22.79:12.4: who dissipates and doesn’t get clouded.
sn22.79:12.5: And what things do they get rid of and not accumulate?
sn22.79:12.6: They get rid of form and don’t accumulate it.
sn22.79:12.11: And what things do they give up and not grasp?
sn22.79:12.12: They give up form and don’t grasp it.
sn22.79:12.17: And what things do they unmesh and not enmesh?
sn22.79:12.18: They unmesh form and don’t enmesh it.
sn22.79:12.23: And what things do they dissipate and not get clouded by?
sn22.79:12.24: They dissipate form and don’t get clouded by it.
sn22.79:12.28: consciousness and don’t get clouded by it.
sn22.79:13.1: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
sn22.79:13.2: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
sn22.79:13.3: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’
sn22.79:14.1: This is called a mendicant who neither gets rid of nor accumulates, but remains after getting rid. They neither give up nor grasp, but remain after giving up. They neither unmesh nor enmesh, but remain after unmeshing. They neither dissipate nor get clouded, but remain after dissipating.
sn22.79:14.2: And what things do they neither get rid of nor accumulate, but remain after getting rid of them?
sn22.79:14.3: They neither get rid of nor accumulate form, but remain after getting rid of it.
sn22.79:14.4: They neither get rid of nor accumulate feeling …
sn22.79:14.7: consciousness, but remain after getting rid of it.
sn22.79:14.8: And what things do they neither give up nor grasp, but remain after giving them up?
sn22.79:14.9: They neither give up nor grasp form, but remain after giving it up.
sn22.79:14.10: They neither give up nor grasp feeling …
sn22.79:14.13: consciousness, but remain after giving it up.
sn22.79:14.14: And what things do they neither discard nor amass, but remain after discarding them?
sn22.79:14.15: They neither unmesh nor enmesh form, but remain after unmeshing it.
sn22.79:14.16: They neither unmesh nor enmesh feeling …
sn22.79:14.19: consciousness, but remain after unmeshing it.
sn22.79:14.20: And what things do they neither dissipate nor get clouded by, but remain after dissipating them?
sn22.79:14.21: They neither dissipate nor get clouded by form, but remain after dissipating it.
sn22.79:14.22: They neither dissipate nor get clouded by feeling …
sn22.79:14.25: consciousness, but remain after dissipating it.
sn22.79:14.26: When a mendicant’s mind is freed like this, the gods together with Indra, the Divinity, and the Progenitor worship them from afar:
sn22.79:15.2: Homage to you, supreme among men!
